subNodes.conversationText:
"A witch of the woods? A redcap? Zaurus, maybe?"

A woman and a small company of people -- some in rags, some in robes, some in worn armor -- were gathered around a dead body.
"Zaurus? Do you really think Zaurus has started killing random travelers?"
"I don't," she sighed. "I'm just desperate for some sign the trail hasn't gone cold."
"Sign? This isnâ€™t a sign, Mnesse. This is a corpse."
"If the corpse doesn't concern him, it doesn't concern me. Let's move on."

"Let's not be hasty. I'm certain a witch did this," intoned a figure, stepping forward. He wore a red half-mask inscribed with absurd sigils -- the mask of a witch hunter.

A witch hunter! Here, on Eldest Lady's doorstep! Witch hunters had a reputation for stupidity, but for one of them to wander the famously witch-haunted woods of Dudow was beyond stupid.
"I'm not hunting witches. I'm hunting Zaurus."

<FirstName> felt a stabbing pain in <his/her> head. <His/Her> mind went blank.

"Must I fight a magician?" <he/she> thought between ebbing pulses of ice-pick-like pain.

actions.a_parameter_1: Combat can always be skipped. Doing so takes 10 minutes of game time. You do not receive experience points for skipped combats.

subNodes.conversationText: "I'm not hunting witches. I'm hunting Zaurus."

"I thought this expedition was a partnership. I thought we were going to help each other, Syr Megae. 'A magician and a witch hunter working together,' I thought. 'What could we not achieve?' But alas, you care only about this Zaurus."
"It is a partnership, but you misconstrue its nature. I said I would help you pursue your goals insofar as they overlapped with mine, but I never promised to put them before my own."

A man emerged from the shadows of the woods and ran toward the group.

"Someone's coming." The scout pointed toward the witch and Knott. "A strange group. One is -- not human."
The motley company sprang to attention.
Mnesse drew a dagger. "Who are you? Do you have something to do with this body? What is that -- thing that walks beside you? That crow -- is that yours?"
Pharaoh, always in the mood for carrion, had landed next to the corpse to assess it.
"It's <his/her> familiar!" the witch hunter hissed. "A witch! A witch! I knew it!"

<FirstName> felt a stabbing pain in <his/her> head. <His/Her> mind went blank.

"Must I fight a magician?" <he/she> thought between ebbing pulses of ice-pick-like pain.

"The marks of a witch. See?" he said, pointing to stab wounds that looked serious and gruesome but not particularly eldtrich. "I have seen similar marks in the Psalms of Sycorax. A witch has crudely carved her foul runes in this man's flesh."

The path narrowed here, and the brush on either side of it was thick.

Suddenly, an arrow shot by and landed in the grass. Another pierced a nearby tree. <FirstName> heard the report of a firearm -- saw people jumping out of the brush -- heard swords drawn and Pharaoh screaming. Then there was only the pain of headache.
Mnesse and her companions had sprung a trap.

actions.a_parameter_1: Combat can always be skipped. Doing so takes 10 minutes of game time. You do not receive experience points for skipped combats.

subNodes.conversationText: "Witch! Witch!" said a voice from the trees.
Palamon, the magician's friend, stepped into the path. He appeared to be alone. He held out his hands. They were weaponless.
"You are hard to track down. Please, I only want to talk."
"What do you want to talk about?"
"Mnesse Megae, of course. The only person in the world who means anything to me."
"You love her," said the young witch.

"Nothing but love would have persuaded me to leave Jad Bizunta. I was a geomancer of the 34th Tier. Does that mean anything to you? No? Well, it means a lot there. Alas, here I am, driven to the ends of the earth in search of Mnesse's nemesis."
"The witch hunter has persuaded her you know where he is."
"I've gathered as much. Why does she believe him?"

"She's desperate, willing to believe anything. No disposition could please a witch hunter more. Moreover, the last news we had of Zaurus placed him here, and everyone knows that witches rule these woods. It didn't take much to convince her that he enjoyed your protection."
"I am not his protector. I discovered him recently."
"Where? Where is he?" Palamon's jaded manner was gone. What a triumph it would be to bring Mnesse news of Zaurus!
"I've heard his story. I would protect him if it came to that."
"I believe you. It is as I thought."
"One day a few weeks ago, while hunting, I happened upon an unmarked grave in the woods. It's at the edge of a clearing near the southern meadows. Do you know it?"

"I wondered if Zaurus slept there. I hoped very much that he did. I kept the grave a secret, imagining Mnesse's gratitude and surprise if I came to her with news that I'd found her enemy's body. Over the next two days, I dug up the grave. Alas, I found only a skeleton in simple clothes -- maybe Zaurus, maybe not. Actually, it seemed unlikely. We knew Zaurus to be alone; what friend would have buried him? I laughed at my foolishness and began throwing earth back over the bones."

"If only the body had been buried with some token of its identity, I thought. For all I knew, I was burying Zaurus himself, and all my hopes with him. Then I stopped my work. Couldn't I plant such a token? I had a purse of coins from Jad Bizunta, as useless as dross in these lands. I poured the money into the grave. A few coins could not be conclusive proof that a person from Jad Bizunta rested there, but to someone looking for such a man, they might be enough."
Palamon looked hopefully at the young witch.

"Yes, they might be enough -- but how would I convince Mnesse to dig up an unknown grave? Assuming I could, would the coins persaude her that fate had already seen to the thing she most desired?... But if the witch thought to be protecting Zaurus revealed that 'd buried him last winter..."
"I know nothing about her except her knack for inflicting headaches."
"She has both magical and mundane versions of that knack."
"You love her," said the young witch.
"Did she give you permission to follow me?"
"Did she give you permission to follow me?"
"I didn't ask her. She doesn't care much what I do." His dejection was obvious.
"You love her," said the young witch.
"Mnesse's heart belongs to Zaurus. Not romantically, mind you: she just thinks of revenge as fondly as lovers think of love."
"Where is the rest of your merry band?"
"Not here, not nearby. I slipped away from them an hour or so ago. They think I left to hunt -- and I suppose I did in a way. I was hunting for you."
"I know: Talk to a witch; flirt with misfortune. So says our witch hunter. It's worth the risk, though."
"I want to talk to you about Mnesse Megae, the only person in the world who means anything to me."
"I want to talk to you about Mnesse Megae, the only person in the world who means anything to me."
"You love her," said the young witch.
"I know nothing about her except her knack for inflicting headaches."
"Did she give you permission to follow me?"
